nodes.bodyText: Refactor this method to reduce its Cognitive Complexity from 17 to the 15 allowed.
Reduce the total number of break and continue statements in this loop to use at most one.
Make "parser" transient or serializable.
This could be warn level message.

warn is good when it happens rarely and unexpected.
In fact this is absolutely expected situation.
templateData  is not null only for Designer template which extends LitTemplate directly and has to provide render method.
Generally render  method doesn't have to be in the template.
So this parser works only for very specific cases and generally it won't work. So info looks more suitable for me here.
Ok
Could IdCollector be updated to state that also the second parameter is allowed to be null? Maybe this case also needs to be handled there, though seems to only be used in logging.
make static
Could looping through the dependencies somehow be factored out as this method is quite complex.

Unfortunately I failed any attempt to refactor it.
There are too many local variables which are used across the code.
Extracting methods will require very cumbersome return types.
Some more descriptive name on this field would be good.

Oh my god !
:(
This is copy paste of the existing code from NpmTemplateParser  and it's absolutely broken.......
The code is corrected.
Ok, only a failed assertion message in test code but the expected id is label here.

nodes.bodyText:
Yes, it can .
And this is the consequence of not being greedy: it's either greedy or not.
Greedy has issues , not greedy has issues.
This way of parsing doesn't support every case.
Designer is not supposed to use this or we will need to rewrite it (and since designer doesn't support LitTemplate at all it has no sense to guess what is supported and what's not).

Render some HTML if myBool is true

`: html`

Render some other HTML if myBool is false

`} `; And finally : please just let me know how may I solve this : should be "\\\`" considered as a possible inside the content ? pattern for excluding "\`" is most likely not a sloution

nodes.bodyText:
Yes, I think the easiest way would be to change the pattern to accept \` also in the content.
I don't think we should need to handle any unescapes ${...} back to JS, as that would theoretically require a regex handling all possible JS syntax. AFAIK Designer will not generate such, at least not containing a nested escape block.

nodes.bodyText:
My point is :
"\\'" is decoded as two symbols "\" and "`", so it has nothing to do with escaped  "`"
"\'" is decoded as  "`".
So the question is : should "\\'" be also allowed in the content ?
As a result : how may I distinguish "some_number_of\`"  from "another_number_of\ \`"
